-polls:  most recent @ 13%.  German polling has a good track record.
-momentum:  rising polling # for weeks
-media attention:  It has gotten a lot of media attention in recent weeks
-message:  Recently more moderate message.   Embraces angry Germans who got a less generous settlements from VW after the diesel engine efficiency scam.  
-voter apathy:  Because Merkel's party is widely expected to win AGAIN & Schults' to be 2nd AGAIN, both major parties are at risk of voter apathy.   This works in favor of small parties.

@cmeinel: AFD polls between 12-15 percent; meaning its rising rather than falling.
they will land right on 15%. many of the protest voter will vote for this party, even they dont agree with the goals
The polls are clear. But due to the inner conflicts of the AfD it is unlikeley, they get 15% or more

Taking the most recent polls of nine different organizations in the field between 3 and 21 September, the mean comes to 10.42%, with a range of 95% probability between 9.59 and 11.25%. One poll has the Afd at 9%, 4 at 10%, 3 at 11% and one at 12%.
It will be about 10%. The official forecasts are precise, because the creators learned from the mistakes of the BREXIT votum and the US election.
I think AFD will be at around 12%. Merkel will win, but CDU and AFD will loose votes to AFD, as people are unsatisfied with the big parties
The SPD is going to fall hard behind and Merkel CDU/CSU has a strong base and will become the biggest party again.
30% of the voters are undecided, and do not want great coalition
I averaged recent polls and returned a 9.203389831 for AfD, a standard distribution built on that mean puts a 84.1% probability of 5-10% and thus ~16% chance at hitting 10-15%.
Updating for upwards shift in polls per 18.09.17 update: https://www.inwt-statistics.de/blog-artikel-lesen/wahlprognose-fuer-die-bundestagswahl-2017.html#Prognose
Weighted polling gives AfD 10.1% per Pollytix.

9/18/17: In possibly a late swing, several polls are indicating AfD recent support at slightly above 10%: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_German_federal_election,_2017 https://www.economist.com/blogs/graphicdetail/2017/08/daily-chart-7 http://www.dw.com/en/german-election-poll-puts-far-right-afd-in-third-place/a-40551590

http://pollytix.eu/pollytix-german-election-trend/ has the AfD at 10.1% on 18 September, up from 9.9% on 15 September. Polls continue to show an upward trend - e.g. Emnid is giving them 11% in the week of 7-13 September compared to 9% from the week before. From https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_German_federal_election,_2017 , the weighted average of the most recent polls taken between 3 and 14 September by seven different organizations comes to 10.26% with a margin of error of 0.91% (from 11,979 people surveyed). According to this, the AfD is likely to get between 9.35 and 11.17%, which is the 95%  confidence range.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Most recent polling suggests that the AfD might get 10-12% though it has fluctuated between 7 and 15%, suggesting a wide range of possibilities. In the 2013 election, the AfD outperformed all of their previous polling results, suggesting a possible "shy AfD voter" effect.  Local elections do demonstrate the AfD's support growing. In local elections in 2016/17, the AfD regularly posting results in the teens and even above 20% (Saxony-Anhalt and Mecklenburg-Vorpommern) though the three elections this year suggest a tapering off of support to c.6%. There definitely are indications that AfD will improve on their 2013 performance, but the resilience of the CDU in the polls and the failue of the AfD to maintain momentum in local elections suggests gains will be limited.

Ulrike E Franke‏ @RikeFranke  43m43 minutes ago
Ulrike E Franke Retweeted Wahlrecht.de
Another poll has AFD as third-strongest party, a week before the election. 
FDP not doing well enough for CDU-FDP coalition. #BTWUlrike E Franke added, Wahlrecht.de @Wahlrecht_de
Now four pollsters on/over 10; compare 2 days ago http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/570108
AfD is getting more votes in the latest polls, and the protest voters which typically don't participate much in the polls will be on top. Therefore I expect now > 10%.

Eight Days left before the election and the actual polls have numbers around 10% for the Alternative for Germany (AfD). http://www.wahlrecht.de/umfragen/ there was an article in the „Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung“ (FAZ) with reasons why its very hard for the different institutes to make right polls for the AfD http://www.faz.net/aktuell/politik/bundestagswahl/warum-wahlprognosen-ueber-die-afd-unzuverlaessig-sind-15198421.html
- there are always 2% - 3% tolerance in the polls, which is a lot for the little parties
- in the last years the number of swing voters grows with every election, much more in the states of the former GDR, because the people are not bounded too parties very much
- not all people asked by the pollmakers tell the truth, as we see in the past (Brexit and Trump), even more because the AFD is more radical than other serious parties
- the AFD can mobilize more former non-voters who decide very late that they will vote for the party and so this voters are not influence the polls inspired by this article, I take a look on the past elections of the german parliament
- In 2009 the polls before the election had differences up to 2% to the result of the election
- more interesting in 2014 in some polls the AFD had 2,5% or 3%, the result was 4,7% and the „Freie Demokratische Partei“ (FDP) had over 5% in every major poll and the result was 4,8% (which means that both party weren't allowed to participate in the parliament (the minimum is 5%))
https://www.welt.de/politik/wahl/bundestagswahl/article120307258/Institut-Forsa-hat-die-besten-Prognosen-abgegeben.html
http://www.bpb.de/lernen/grafstat/grafstat-bundestagswahl-2013/146600/mb-03-22-genauigkeit-von-wahlprognosen The institutes who are making the major polls in germany often calculate with such things, but this facts are interesting anyway and it's possible that all the facts happen at once and then it is likely that the AFD is getting more than 10%.

Best data source I'm aware of: https://www.inwt-statistics.de/blog-artikel-lesen/wahlprognose-fuer-die-bundestagswahl-2017.html#Prognose. Aggregates weekly polls from 7 polling institutes, weighting each according to historical accuracy and adjusting for possible political bias. Using their 80% prediction interval as of 11.09.17 (AfD result to fall between 7.7% and 10.9%) I read off corresponding probabilities for results in the 0-5%, 5-10%, 10-15% and 15%+ brackets.
Additional data points considered:
1. Previous Bundestag elections: of very limited use as the AfD has only contested one previous election (2013). Since then the AfD has radically overhauled its policy platform and leadership to the extent it is practically a different party. Seeking a "cut-off point" for the purposes of this prediction, I would say the AfD in its current form "dates" from Frauke Petry's assumption of the party leadership in July 2015 (https://www.ft.com/content/456815bc-9291-11e7-a9e6-11d2f0ebb7f0). 
2. Landtag elections: data too limited to have much predictive power but of some use as a sense check. In total the AfD has contested 14 Landtag elections, each in a different Land. 6 of these fell before its radical policy shift in July 2015 so I would say these are of very limited use for this forecast. The remaining 8 elections span the period March 2016 - May 2017:
- differences between Laender: ignored for the purposes of this very simplistic sense check. I understand the Land electoral systems are broadly similar to the Bundestagwahl (i.e. based on overall voting proportions) and that AfD support has not tended to cluster strongly by geography (https://www.tagesschau.de/inland/afd-waehler-101.html)
- time trend: the 8 election results follow a broad trend similar to national polling (per weekly poll aggregates) with the highest results in autumn 2016 and a fall back into the single digits in 2017. Supports the view that the best predictors of AfD vote share are events and trends at the national level. The simple average of the three 2017 Landtag election results is 6.5%: in the 5-10% range. 
3. Possible events between now and 24 September, not factored into today's polls, which could affect AfD result:
a) Events which would affect AfD support directly:
- generally difficult to predict given AfD voting patterns not yet well-understood (https://www.tagesschau.de/inland/afd-waehler-101.htmlb). The rise in AfD support in autumn 2015 continuing into 2016 was associated with the migration crisis and policy response by the German government. However, a significant change in this policy area between now and 24 September is very unlikely. 
b) Events which would affect other parties' support and indirectly affect AfD's share of the vote:
- too difficult to predict. AfD votes have not been drawn overwhelmingly from former supporters of any one party so an event increasing or reducing support for another party would not have a clear knock-on effect on AfD support.
AfD is gaining some ground in the latest polls. It's really tight around 10%.

AfD has been on an upward trend for quite some time.   I suspect that this is because it has embraced some issues like appropriate compensation for owners of VW diesel cars.   For quite some time now, this election has looked pretty certain for Merkel and her party.   I've read that when such is the case, 3rd parties do significantly better in the voting; I suppose this is because people feel it's "safe" to cast a protest vote.   Of the 4 most recent polls, only one is below 10% and one is @ 12%.  Pollytix (a 538-type website) has AfD @ 9.9%.
Looks like AfD is creeping up. Time to keep closer track.

My own bias, of course, does not favor the AfD; to put it very nicely. However, it's highly depressing to see one pollster after another finding more than 10% support in this population. Just imagine how my newsticker archive looks: August 13,  all pollsters below 10.
September 10, two pollsters over 10 and ALL pollster moving 1 pct point upwards.
September 13, two pollsters over 10 and one pollster moving to 11% from 10.5%.
September 15, three pollsters over/on 10 and one pollster moving to 12% from 11%.

Poll from Infratest dimap taken between 12 and 13 September gives the AfD 12%, up from 11% last week, the first time in more than seven months that this organization (or any other) has been so high. To confirm the trend, Forschungsgruppe Wahlen has the Afd at 10%, up from the 9% it reported a week ago. Also, http://pollytix.eu/pollytix-german-election-trend/ has its weighted average at 9.9%.

AfD at new highs (of 16%) in one recent opinion poll.
http://www.politico.eu/article/far-right-afd-hits-new-highs-in-germany-wide-poll-state-elections/ While this seems overstated (and a senior party official speaking in defence of German soldiers during the two world wars will not help matters), it might be enough to warrant a slight increase in the 10-15% box.
Shifting a little higher as the AfD has risen a bit.

I looked at the previous election in 2013. There were a number of polling firms active. The data from the company Forsa gave the best material from which to predict the outcome in 2013. When I use only their data from 2017 the prediction for AfD is 9,5% (95% confidence interval is (rounded) 8% and 11%). The probability that the score for AfD is under 10% is 76%.

http://www.dw.com/en/angela-merkel-has-a-huge-lead-in-polls-ahead-of-german-election-but-are-they-accurate/a-40472278 "There has been considerable speculation about whether public opinion polls downplay the amount of support enjoyed by the xenophobic right-wing populist Alternative for Germany (AfD) party, which currently polls at around 11 percent. Surveys failed to predict the AfD's greatest regional election successes last year, when the party sometimes got over 20 percent of the vote, but have been more accurate in elections this year. "We're assuming that the AfD is correctly reflected in our latest numbers," Siegel said. "The difference between our final opinion surveys and the actual AfD election results weren't very large."
"With online polls we don't have the problem that extreme positions are too rarely represented," said Geissler – YouGov also puts AfD support at approximately 11 percent." "Germany is currently governed by a so-called grand coalition of the CDU-CSU and Social Democrats, and if history is any indication, there could be an electoral backlash. Siegel said that the small parties will "have a chance to profit." Geissler sees a similar scenario developing in the past few polls. "I can imagine that both the CDU-CSU and the SPD will lose significant support before the election," he said. "The trend is toward the smaller parties – and not just in our surveys."
The key for all parties, but especially the larger ones, is how well they can mobilize their usual voters. The relatively high number of Germans who will vote early by mail, estimated at around one-third, could favor parties with established hardcore supporters.

http://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/afd-right-wing-populists-to-take-seats-in-german-parliament-a-1166794.html "...Germany now finds itself faced with a historic turning point. On Sept. 24, it looks as though a party that has racist and nationalist tendencies will win seats in the Bundestag. The AfD is currently between 8 and 11 percent in public opinion polls. And the party won't just change the face of the German parliament, but likely also its culture of political debate. If the AfD ends up with around 10 percent of the vote, it will send 70 lawmakers to parliament. One of them will be Jens Maier, who is second on the AfD's state list from Saxony. Maier wasn't just present when Björn Höcke, floor leader for the AfD in the state of Thuringia, notoriously referred to the Holocaust Memorial in Berlin as a "monument to shame" and called for a "180-degree shift in our memory politics" at a Dresden ballroom in January. He warmed up the crowd before Höcke's tirade. In a brief introduction, he said that after World War II, the Germans were told that they were no longer worth anything: "I declare herewith this cult of guilt to finally be over!" Maier crowed. The crowd went wild." Comment:   As Angela Merkel seems to be on a trajectory towards victory, the real motivation of this election lies in the makings of a coalition.  AfD is highly motivated and has already achieved much by having seats in 13 of 16 German states. Election polling confirms more support for AfD but it's really more about voter turnout.  The AfD narrative is validated not only by Trump's victory but also by his continued bold, anti-immigration, white supremacist rhetoric and actions . I believe the AfD will  get over 10% based on polling of course but the main thing is motivation for turnout. AfD understands this and yet there are also other forces in the third party category who want to stop them. Today, Merkel announced that she would not agree to any limit on refugees coming into Germany. She hasn't wavered on this so not sure it matters to most voters at this point except for the extremists.. giving them more motivation to vote; all about the turnout.
No suprise here ... Latest polling "aus Deutschland" ... https://www.merkur.de/politik/bundestagswahl-2017-afd-in-neuer-umfrage-hinter-linken-prognose-zr-8076933.html

Polls have it near 11% and 2016 turnouts suggest it may be near the 15% mark.

http://pollytix.eu/pollytix-german-election-trend/ has inched up to 9.6% on 12 September. Updating my 11 Sep forecast of 30/70. now using the 8 latest polls from different polling organizations listed in wikipedia who were in the field between 31 Aug and 11 Sep. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_German_federal_election,_2017.  Their weighted average as calculated by me now comes to 9.83%, with a margin of error of 0.90% (over a total of 12,479 responses). Accordingly, the range within 95% confidence limits has become 8.93-10.73, giving a 43% probability of 10.01% or more.
upward trending AfD and SPD losing support after debate

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_German_federal_election,_2017. Their weighted average now comes to 9.47%, with a margin of error of 0.86% (over a total of 13,540 responses). The range within 95% confidence then becomes 8.61-10.33.
Polls show about 10%, but steadily declining so 5-10% is most likely.

9/9/17: Average of most-recent eight polls results for AfD via source below = 9.56% https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_German_federal_election,_2017 The Economist's  "election poll tracker" currently indicates 9.7% support for AfD (with a slight upward recent trend): https://www.economist.com/blogs/graphicdetail/2017/08/daily-chart-7 Financial Times "poll of polls" (weighted average) currently indicates 9% support for AfD, with a recent upward trend showing https://ig.ft.com/germany-poll-tracker/

Anti EU rhetoric is rife in Europe and around the world. However, the Brexit result for the UK whether right or wrong for the country has caused political distabilisation, a weaker pound and a level of uncertainty for our future. The rest of Europe looks on with interest but as one of the founders of the EU with a solid economy Germany will be less include towards the divisive nature of this party and its support and alignment with their friend the for,ready UKIP leader. His racist and divine nature will not go down well in a united Germany.
Still hoping that the extrem right positions of the AfD will hurt their vote share, but etching upwards to follow polls. Rather unlikely for them to fail getting 5%..

After the debates on German Television there are a few actual polls from different sources. Now its between 8 and 11% for the Alternative for Germany (AfD). The people use the tv-debates for their Decision but a lot of voters are still not sure for which party they will vote. The AfD is a protest party and they are using their image to get more votes for example with controversial statements.
The chance is rising that the AfD is getting more then 10%. http://www.wahlrecht.de/umfragen/
http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/bundestagswahl-2017-warum-die-kleinen-parteien-entscheidend-sind-a-1166576.html

There are only 5 polling results for september 2017, so we should be cautious about these. However: these results show a rise for AfD which confirmed a trend that started in July. So I am moving from my former position (lower than 10%) to a "I don't know"-position giving 50% probability each way. I will be watching the new polling results.

Going purely by polls taken between 22 Aug and 06 Sep and listed here https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_German_federal_election,_2017 My weighted average comes to 9.46% for AfD (close to the more sophisticated calculation of 9.4% in http://pollytix.eu/pollytix-german-election-trend/ ). Further, with a margin of error of 0.88%, I calculate the 95% probability range to be between 8.58 and 10.35%. About 6 weeks ago, on 19 July, I had calculated AfD's weighted average to be 8.19% with a margin of error of 0.82%, at which time I gave them only a 4% chance of exceeding a 10% vote share. It looks like the blandness and lack of significant differentiation to date between Merkel and Schulz's campaigns is inclining some voters in a sort of protest towards the margins (especially from CDU to AfD) in the expectation that there will in all probability be another Grand Coalition of CDU/SPD.

I wanted to lower my 5--10 bracket to half, but forecasting rule number 9,876 says never to move more than in 15% point steps. Like others I've noticed a disturbing upswing in poll sentiments for the AfD. If Brexit and Trump teaches me anything (a comparison class), then voters in Germany simply will go for moral hazard and vote far-right wingers. I'm more confident about that they're getting into parliament, though. Again, because virtually no state poll (Bavaria etc.) see them below 5% @shivadiva
While populism is on the rise throughout Europe experiences so far watching President Trump have been negative and seemed to have created some backlash.

For the polling period between 24 Aug and 04 Sep, of the most recent 5 polls listed below, one has the AfD at 11%, another at 10.5 and a third at 10%. The other two are at 8%. This is actually the first week in several months that any poll has given the AfD more than 10%. http://pollytix.eu/pollytix-german-election-trend/#koalr The weighted average is 9.4% and I've calculated the combined margin of error to be about 0.8%, so there's a 95% probability of the vote share being between 8.4 and 10.2%. However, I'm giving the AfD a higher probability of getting more than 10% because of uncertainty generated by the substantial difference between different polls , the upward trend in AfD's polling, and the possibility that a significant number of voters still haven't made up their minds.

Generally these parties get a few more % than polls say. So, add 1-3%. The moving average for last month is approx. 9%, so decent chance of 10-11%. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_German_federal_election,_2017#2017

8/31/17: Some recent poll results indicate AfD support at around 10%. Noting from other comments that many may currently be 'undecided'... https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_German_federal_election,_2017 ,,,Also items such as this though: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-germany-election-afd-idUSKCN1B91F3

In previous elections the AfD has increased it poll percent over the summer, but dropped back in September. There are a lot of voters who say they have not made up their minds. I suspect that AfD voters are more likely to have already made their minds up, so my forecast is that the AfD share of the vote will fall between now and the election. But maybe this time it will be different.

German and don't know who to vote for? Ask the Vote-O-Meter Shalal (2017) August 30, states that: Three weeks before Germany’s election and with at least one poll suggesting nearly half of all voters don’t know what they will do, the government has unveiled an updated online tool to help them decide. Around two dozen young people from around Germany helped launch the “Wahl-O-Mat” (roughly Vote-O-Meter) on Wednesday -- an online website that matches people with a party after they answer a series of policy questions (para 1-2). Merkel is widely expected to win a record-tying fourth term, with her CDU/CSU conservatives maintaining a two-digit lead over the SPD despite continuing concerns over her 2015 decision to allow in over a million migrants (para.6). A poll by the Allensbach institute last week showed that 46 percent of voters had not made up their minds on how to vote -- the highest rate since in two decades so close to an election, which is being held on Sept. 24 (para. 8). “We’ve seen that about six percent of those who were not planning to participate in the election changed their minds after using the tool,” he said (para 13). “Interest is definitely higher in this election, but so is uncertainty. It remains to see how that will affect participation. It could well be that if people remain uncertain that they simply stay home” (para 17). Shalal, A. (2017). German and don't know who to vote for? Ask the Vote-O-Meter. Reuters World News. Retrieved from
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-germany-election-idUSKCN1BA21B

In the current cycle of polls, two are showing the AfD at 10% , two are at 9%, and the lowest is 7%. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_German_federal_election,_2017 I calculate from these polls that there is currently a 95% chance of the AfD getting between 7.6 and 9.4%. However, the spread between 7 and 10 has made me increase the chances of "more than 10%"  from 4% a month ago to 9% today. EDIT:  I will be changing this forecast.  I misread a chart.
Support seems to be holding steady in the 7% to 9% range.

Yesterday, an INSA poll came out giving AfD 10%, so I flipped my forecast, increasing 10%+.
But today newer polls by GMS & Forsa give it 7.0 & 8.0% respectively.
Pollytix has adjusted its forecast from 8.6% yesterday to 8.4% today.
I over-reacted, I think, and am re-balancing my forecast.
Since May 15th the polls for AfD have been consistently below 10% and never below 6.5%. The range of the 95% confidence interval is (low) 8% and (high) 9%.

German election 2017 poll tracker
AfD @ 8% Leach and Stabe (2017) Aug 8, states that: Angela Merkel is vying for a fourth term as chancellor when Germany elects a new Bundestag on September 24.
The FT’s time-weighted average of seven pollsters’ latest polls of voting intention suggests that Ms Merkel’s Christian Democratic Union and its Bavarian sister party, the Christian Social Union, should comfortably remain the largest party. But under Germany’s proportional representation system this is unlikely to translate into a majority of seats in the new parliament. How the other parties perform will determine the coalition that forms the next German government (para. 1-3). Leach, A. & Stabe, M. (2017). German election 2017 poll tracker. Financial Times. German Elections. Retrieved from
https://ig.ft.com/germany-poll-tracker/
Going to adjust further as we get closer but right now the party is polling around 9%.

FWIW: Three of last four polls listed, first source below report AfD support at 9%; election is still several weeks away though.  Also, details of the recent Hamburg 'migrant' attacker story could shine a spotlight upon immigration...perhaps for a minority of voters. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_German_federal_election,_2017 http://www.reuters.com/article/us-germany-security-hamburg-idUSKBN1AE0CV

Less then Two Months left before the election in Germany. They are different 
polls, and they see the AFD between 7 and 9 percent at the moment. http://www.wahlrecht.de/umfragen/.
What will happen in September? First of all it is very unlikely that the AFD get less than 5 percent in the elections. Like in other Countries in Europe there is a potential for populist parties in germany. 12 Years with chancelor Angela Merkel, her decision to receiving a large number of refugees in 2015, the sanctions against russia, the feeling that politics and media are moving to the left or simply protest against the system are some reasons that the AFD is getting more than 5 percent. So, a number between 5% and 10% has the highest probability for me. Reasons for this forecast are the different internal problems of the party. For example problems in the states of germany. The parliamentary group of the parliament of Baden-Württemberg had a problem with antisemitic members and was temporarily divided. In Saxony-Anhalt different wings of the party fight against each other. These problems are not very helpful for a good campaign for the upcoming election in september. 
https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/AfD_Baden-W%C3%BCrttemberg#Auseinandersetzung_um_Wolfgang_Gedeon
https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/AfD_Sachsen-Anhalt#Innerparteiliche_Konflikte But the core voters don't care that the party is moving more and more to the right the last years and that the internal problems of the AFD paralyse the campaign. The voters who are unhappy with the status quo of political system are a safe basis for the AFD.
Also, many ideas of the AFD are too extrem for the most voters in germany. The ideas of the party for example about culture, religion or family are not in common with the ideals of a large number of voters. 
But is there a chance that the AFD will get more than 10 percent? Of course, there is a chance. For example if more terroristic attacks will happen in the Western World and especially in Germany. Key issues of the AFD are the higher public safety and the repatriation of refugees. Terrorist groups use the routes for refugees for their assassins and with the claim for more security and less refugees the AFD can probably get more votes in the election. Also in some polls the party already has 9 percent and there are also voters who make their decision very late. So more than 10 percent are also possible at the moment.
15 percent or more are very, very unlikely at the moment. But we will see more in the next weeks when the campaign will start their hot phase.
I am guessing AfD will have a 9% at best. Let's see.

downward trend of the party because of:
- upheaval in the party (very bad: if parties are not united, they cannot win)
- investigations against Frauke Petry, one of the top AfD officials in the German State Saxony
- problems with the registration process at the German State of Lower Saxony
- again problems with right wing extremists in the party (AfD of Lower Saxony and in Baden-Württemberg --> very bad since this scares non-extremist right wing voters to vote for the party) The relatively disunited appearance of the AfD is going to be a serious problem for them: it is not easy to see who and what will reunite the party… may be the elections as such?

If it is a correct theory that the right-wing populist movement in the US and Europe is linked in some way and that election results in one country have been influencing the polls in other countries then it appears that the tide reached its high point in the middle of 2016 and started to ebb (in Europe) from November 2016. Each country saw slight differences in when the high point was reached but by mid-2017 it can be seen that AfD's percentage had fallen from around a high point of around 14% a year ago to about 7% now. In the last 3 months it dropped by about 30%. If that trend continued at the same rate they would get about 5% on election day. 
Of course there is no reason to assume that the trend will continue or that it will be at the same rate. As the German election nears and campaigns start the changes are likely to be more volatile. In the 2013 German election AfD increased its support (according to the polls) between June and the election from about 3% to 4.7%  (having dropped from around 5% in the April).  Each country is of course different and even if general trends affect voters in all western countries, the electoral systems mean that voters wanting to make a protest vote or a negative vote or a tactical vote (by voting for an candidate they don't support to stop the candidate they hate getting elected) will do things differently. In the US for example there were really only two credible parties to vote for, in France the multiple rounds system allows a vote for who you like in the first round and a vote against who you hate in the second round, in the UK there are multiple parties but in each constituency tactical voting can be used to weaken or beat the party that has the most support, but less than majority support. In Germany where seats are proportional voters have less incentive to do negative or tactical voting so it would be expected that the votes cast would be close to what the polls had forecast. 
In the June UK election the result was said to be a great shock, but the polls had showed support for the Conservatives was dropping very sharply and support for Labour was rising very sharply for the month before the election. This was so sharp that the composite polls (that that took the rolling average of all polls) were a few days behind the true trend, which did make it appear that a hung parliament was likely. 
It seems very unlikely that any of the German parties will fight such a bad campaign as the UK Conservatives did (it was so bad that its surprising that no one has suggested that Mrs May's manifesto of spectacularly unpopular, irrelevant ideas must have been concocted by Russia to help Labour; did she really think that taking money from her pensioner supporters, and bringing back the school system from the 1950s and reintroducing fox hunting would bring in the votes?)

Contrary to few German in-country observers who have noticed that the AfD had been "losing" in sentiment polls, I do not see the demise of voter support. I would even eliminate the idea of the AfD NOT entering the Bundestag for hard and soft reasons.  The hard indicators are the 2017-vote shares IN ELECTORAL STRONGHOLDS OF THE SOCIAL DEMOCRATIC PARTY in the West. If the AfD manages to "win", say, in Dortmund, they surely can win other precincts as well. In Dortmund (with 60,000 to 80,000 actual votes per precinct), the AfD's absolute and relative votes were: — 4979 votes, or 9.2% in city precinct one (1/4),
— 3993 votes, or 7.9% in city precinct two (2/4),
— 6302 votes, or 8.7% in city precinct three (3/4),
— 5901 votes, or 7.5% in city precinct four (4/4). Hence, the performance of far-right conservatives within the boundaries of the two to four SPD-gerrymandered precincts and wards should be telling indicator to us. The Dortmund citizens steadily adopted the AfD as a ticket and the absolute and relative votes in this city grew from: — 5188 votes, or 3.5% in federal elections 2013, precinct one (1/2),
— 5571 votes, or 4.1% in federal elections 2013, precinct two (2/2),
— 6835 votes, or 3.4% in city council elections 2014, citywide precinct,
— 11693 votes, or 5.9% in European parliamentary elections 2014, citywide precinct. They consistently touched the five-percent hurdle before the refugee crisis and they surely surpassed it afterwards.  The Dortmund case represents a speculative but reasonable MINIMUM VOTE OUTCOME AND FLOOR for the AfD in September. It is a university town with a large second-generation immigrant population from Turkey, Poland, Romania, foreign exchange students mainly from India and China on the one hand, and a vibrant Nazi youth community on the other. Resistance to right-wing positions is strongest, here, and right-wing resistance to that, too. Interestingly, the forces cancelled each other in terms of actual violence against refugees. Dortmund has not seen too many such acts, compared to the unusual spike all over Germany. Source: http://wahlen.digistadtdo.de/ (in German) @Rene Raahul_Kumar @shivadiva @lsgold7

I'll tax rich Germans more, says SPD leader Schulz Nienaber and Hansen (2017) Mon Jun 19, states that: Germany's Social Democrats (SPD) said on Monday they would tax the rich more and low earners less, making a play to win back working-class voters as the party seeks to revive a flagging election campaign. SPD leader Martin Schulz hopes to unseat Chancellor Angela Merkel in the Sept. 24 election, but the center-left party has lost momentum in the polls since making gains following his nomination in January. "We'll reduce the tax burden for small and medium-sized incomes and we'll support families," Schulz told reporters. "Our proposal is good not just for Germany but also for Europe," he said, adding it would help stimulate domestic demand and suck in more imports from other European countries. Schulz said the SPD would increase Germany's top income tax rate to 45 percent from 42 percent, while lifting the threshold from which the rate applied to 76,000 euros ($85,000) from around 54,000 euros. The SPD, currently the junior partner in Merkel's ruling coalition, would also raise the special income levy for those earning 250,000 euros or more to 48 percent from 45 percent. The plans highlight the SPD's aim of putting social justice at the heart of the election campaign. But the topic has yet to strike much of a chord with voters, with opinion polls showing the conservatives led by Merkel, who is seeking a fourth term in office, holding a double-digit lead (para. 1-7). Nienaber, M. & Hansen, H. (2017). I'll tax rich Germans more, says SPD leader Schulz. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from

The cutoff between over/under 10 % is tricky. For most of the time since December 2015, AfD's support has exceeded 10 % (touching 15 % at best), however since November 2016 the trend has been steadily downward and has reached 8 % in the beginning of June 2017.  Looking at the poll trends of the other parties, it seems AfD's support is most closely (inversely) correlated with CDU, which is intuitive for a "protest" party. The main driver behind the flux of support between the two parties seems to have been the migrant crisis, not so much terrorist attacks. There was no uptick in AfD support after the Berlin Christmas market attack for example, but the general rise and subsequent fall in support seems to have coincided with the onset and then abating of the migrant situation. All in all, I feel CDU is likely to finish strongly in the run up to the elections, leaving AfD with roughly 8-10 % of the vote.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_German_federal_election,_2017

Nice question… I like! Given the polling averages, todays probability of the AfD exceeding 5 percent is 99,5 percent (see polling aggregation, here: https://www.inwt-statistics.de/blog-artikel-lesen/wahlprognose-fuer-die-bundestagswahl-2017.html#Prognose). So I think 5 percent is the lower end of the AfD's popular vote. So what is the upper end? The highest value ever measured was 15,5 on 26 September 2016 by INSA. This was a the climax of the refugee crisis… So, this is probably the upper end. (see all polls, here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_German_federal_election,_2017) What has to happen that the AfD has more than 15 percent? It is all about media agenda setting: Best would be a flood of refugees AND a terrorist attack AND integration policy becomes a big issue AND the Chancellor ignoring the problems, as she did in 2015/16. 
* Refugees crisis: rather unlikely; Merkel did all she could in EU (Frontex) and international relations (EU-Turkey relations; African policy) to lower the refugee inflow to Europe. She knows that this could strengthen the AfD very much - and that it could be disastrous for Italy, France etc. There is a big interest in strengthening pro-European parties, so leaders of European countries all will avoid strengthening right wing parties, i.e. avoiding a new refugee crisis. And many in the CDU do not want to see a situation like in 2015/16, again.
* Terrorist attack: likely to very likely; I do not hope it but Germany is a target, for sure. If we have an attack it depends on its scope. CDU has built up some resilience regarding the AfD - but some voters did not forget how Merkel acted in 2015/16. AfD would profit from a large to medium scale terrorist attack, for sure.
* Integration becomes a big issue in the campaign: likely, mostly because the SPD could set it on the agenda in order to gain a considerable vote share among leftist voters. That would directly help AfD. However, CDU is trying to make some hardliner statements on this issue, as well. They are prepared. 
* Chancellor that is ignoring the problems / reality: Extremely unlikely. Angela Merkel is the Queen of making strong policy shifts that do actually feel remarkably 'soft'… she did so many times: Euro crisis, atomic energy policy, refugees.
* Even if all these key factors will be combined, it is not sure that the AfD will raise above 15 percent since the Government can act and will act - and, most notably, the Government has shifted credibly towards homeland security: so the voters will not blame the CDU so much. (And we should not forget: If there is somebody in the world who can somehow handle a crisis without harming herself: it is Angela Merkel!) - I think, given that the CDU - since 2015 - has done a lot to defend its policy position against the AfD: it is very unlikely that the AfD will have more than 15 percent of the popular vote.

What has to happen that the AfD is below 5 percent? Clearly, controversies among the top party leaders. Unlikely, however. The party has removed notorious troublemakers. And everybody knows the golden rule of campaigning: Suspend all inner quarrels! May be, there could be a scandal - but even if: it would do harm only to some of the party leaders, not all. And the electorate of the AfD is rather stable: it consists of critics of the German refugee policy AND (never forget!) critics of the policies to 'rescue the Euro'… The AfD is not (only) a right-wing populist party, it - too - is a 'national liberal' party with outspoken liberal attitudes concerning economic policy, and it is cultivating a soft (!) Euroscepticism (comparable to the Cameron position in the UK). (One should not put the AfD in a basket with Trump, neither the Leave campaigners in UK, Geert Wilders, or Le Pen - that would be wrong.)

Will it be below or above the 10 percent threshold? Very hard to say. Given the current polls and the momentum, it is more likely that they will be below 10 percent. However, as I pointed out when I discussed the Angela Merkel question several times: we still have to go about 14 weeks until election… that is very much. And the AfD is a party that can easily profit from Government failure and certain media agendas (which are hard to predict). Particularly for the AfD it is true: there is so much contingency! I would estimate that the 95 percent confidence interval for the AfD is somewhere between 6 and 12 percent. For the below 10 percent option (but more than 5 percent) some forecasters estimate more than 66 percent. That seems overrated to me. German electoral politics is comparably less complex, voters are comparably less volatile than in France and Italy - but still, there is considerable leeway. BTW: One should not expect underestimation of the AfD vote share by pollsters. They got it mostly right in the regional elections… And see the table of Nate Silver on over- and underestimation of right wing parties, here: https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/le-pen-is-in-a-much-deeper-hole-than-trump-ever-was/. There is no (!) evidence that right wing parties are systematically underestimated by pollsters. - The best polling aggregation is this: https://www.inwt-statistics.de/blog-artikel-lesen/wahlprognose-fuer-die-bundestagswahl-2017.html#Prognose. A COMMENT ON THE ELECTORAL SYSTEM: 
The 'second vote' (Zweitstimme) is the only vote that determines the seat share of a party in the Bundestag. The 'first vote' (Erststimme) does only determine which person will sit in parliament for the respective parties in a given one man district. It is theoretically possible to gain more mandates in the Erststimme (one man electoral districts, first-past-the-post) than you gained in the Zweitstimme (proportional representation). However, the seat shares of the proportional representation will be uphold by 'compensation mandates' (Ausgleichsmandate). THEREFORE: You cannot effectively vote for two parties! That is not possible. To cut a long story short: You can take the polls as a valid information of the seat share a party gets. Do not get confused. The important vote in Germany, the one that determines the majorities in the Bundestag is - paradoxically - the 'second vote' ('Zweitstimme'). - And read the question: They clearly refer to 'popular vote' - this is 'Zweitstimme' / 'second vote'. - On the evening of election day nobody in Germany cares about the 'first vote' (Erststimme). Do not do so, either! German electoral system is simple: proportional representation - no the-winner-takes-it-all troubles like in the UK and Electoral College. (In Germany, nobody can understand that there is a US President considered legitimate although he lost the popular vote… that seems crazy to us.) ADDENDUM: All polls in Germany refer to the 'second vote' (Zweitstimme) - since it is the only one that really counts in terms of seat shares.

With AfD losing support in recent polls (high single digits on average), it seems as though they'll be in the 5-10% range (articles 1 and 3 below). What gives me pause is the complexity of the electoral system (article 2), in which a voter can vote for a candidate (say, from CDU) for their district, but then cast the second vote for a party (say, AfD). This could allow for a party like AfD to potentially exceed polling expectations, especially if the populist trend isn't well-captured by the polls. http://www.reuters.com/article/us-germany-election-schleswig-holstein-idUSKBN1820JE http://www.dw.com/en/race-for-the-bundestag-2017-how-does-the-german-general-election-work/a-37805756 http://www.latimes.com/world/europe/la-fg-germany-election-trump-20170602-story.html
